DT Article
TI Haplothrips zabolius sp. n., a new species from Sistan & Baluchestan
   province, southeast of Iran (Thysanoptera: Phlaeothripidae).
AU Minaei, K. (kminaei@shirazu.ac.ir) 
   Alavi, J.
   Rashid, B.
   Mokhtari, A.
SO Journal of Entomological Society of Iran
VL 35
IS 4
PS 39-44
PD Win 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Haplothrips zabolius sp. n. is described from two plant species, Cynodon
   dactylon (Poaceae) and Plantago lanceolata (Plantaginaceae) from the
   southeast of Iran. The new species is apparently close to some
   grass-living Haplothrips species: H. aculeatus (Fabricius), H.
   eragrostidis Priesner and H. hukkineni Priesner. Most specimens of the
   new species have only one sense cone on the antennal segment III, but it
   is unusual among Iranian members of the genus in having another sense
   cone on the antennal segment III in a few specimens.
C1 Minaei, K.; Shiraz Univ, Coll Agr, Shiraz, Iran, Iran.
EM kminaei@shirazu.ac.ir

   Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   species] [ / Plantago lanceolata / ] [Iran /  / New species from plant
   host].

DT Article
TI Revision of European Hyotheriinae (Suidae) and Doliochoeridae
   (Mammalia).
AU Pickford, Martin (martin.pickford@mnhn.fr) 
SO Muenchner Geowissenschaftliche Abhandlungen Reihe A Geologie und
   Palaeontologie
VL 44
PS 1-270
PD Dezember 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This monograph treats bunodont suoids mainly from Europe, some from
   Africa and in passing mentions some Chinese material. It is an in-depth
   revision of the Hyotheriinae (Suidae) and Doliochoeridae (previously
   called the Palaeochoeridae) from Oligocene and Early to basal Middle
   Miocene levels, for which a summary of European Oligo-Miocene
   biostratigraphy is provided. Much of the early work on Oligo-Miocene
   suids of Europe was carried out prior to the publication of the "Origin
   of Species" by Darwin (1859) a period during which ranges of
   morphological and metric variation were poorly understood or
   underestimated. In order to understand the historical background of the
   naming of genera and species of hyotheres and doliochoeres prior to
   Peters, 1869, the first paper which demonstrated the presence of sexual
   dimorphism in fossil suids, a detailed review of the old literature is
   included. This review attempts to explain the intellectual milieu, with
   its preconceptions, contradictions and belief values, within which the
   nascent taxonomy was done. It is clear that many of the early
   researchers were aware of the vastness of geological time, even if some
   of them underestimated its depth, but few if any of them resolved the
   succession of events [long dash] what we would now term biostratigraphy.
   The palaeontologists were thus severely handicapped when it came to
   interpreting their fossil samples. It is also clear that until Darwin's
   (1859) publication, few researchers interpreted their fossils within a
   framework of natural selection. Until 1869, most workers on fossil suids
   did not take into account sexual dimorphism, some of them putting males
   and females into different genera. None of the earlier studies undertook
   statistical analyses of the fossils, but over the past Century some
   localities have yielded important samples, by which intraspecific
   variability could be documented. The list of European localities which
   have yielded rich fossil assemblages has increased to the point where it
   is now possible to be reasonably confident of the ranges of metric and
   morphological variation in many of the taxa. Nevertheless, there are
   several genera and species which are still relatively poorly represented
   in the fossil record. It is concluded that the holotype of Choeropotamus
   meisneri from Rappenfluh, Switzerland, is so poorly preserved that the
   taxon is a nomen vanum. It could represent a suid, but appurtenance to
   Choeropotamidae cannot be excluded, although, on the basis of its
   radicular morphology, the specimen is unlikely to represent a
   doliochoerid. For over a Century, this species was included in
   Hyotherium on the basis of fossils from sites other than the type
   locality. Fossils from these sites are here attributed to Hyotherium
   major which, despite its name, is smaller than Hyotherium medium.
   Hyotherium medium is described in detail and a lectotype nominated from
   the sample from Mosskirch, Germany, that was studied by Von Meyer
   (1834). Much new material of Hyotherium major and Hyotherium soemmeringi
   is described. Good samples of Aureliachoerus aurelianensis and
   Aureliachoerus minus are described, which throw a great deal of light on
   morphometric variability in these species. The genus Aureliachoerus is
   closely related to the African genus Nguruwe. The genus Palaeochoerus is
   likely to represent a suid rather than a peccary-like mammal, which
   makes continued use of the family name Palaeochoeridae Stehlin, 1909,
   caduque. Doliochoeridae Simpson, 1945, is here utilised for this family
   of suoids. Among the Doliochoeridae, there has been a great deal of
   confusion generated by mis-attribution of fossils between Doliochoerus
   and Propalaeochoerus. For example, a most recent diagnosis of
   Doliochoerus includes characters gleaned from specimens of
   Propalaeochoerus. A new genus of doliochoerid, Bransatochoerus, is
   erected for the abundant material from Coderet, France, which has unique
   features of the post-cranial skeleton suggesting that this species dug
   its own burrows, in which it lived and sometimes died. Additional
   material of Doliochoerus pusillus is illustrated, as are some
   interesting samples of Lorancahyus hypsorhizus. Much new material is
   added to Dubiotherium waterhousi, previously known only by two
   mandibles. The monograph ends with comments on the phylogeny of
   doliochoerids and suids, but it is stressed that a great deal of further
   study is required to resolve the phylogenetic issues. These studies must
   take into account the post-cranial skeleton, as well as the
   dento-gnathic record upon which most previous attempts at phylogeny
   reconstruction were based. For instance, the species Doliochoerus
   pusillus possesses metapodials that are suid-like, rather than
   doliochoerid-like, which makes for a contradiction, as was pointed out
   by Hellmund & Heizmann (2015).
C1 Pickford, Martin; Sorbonne Universities - CR2P, MNHN, CNRS, UPMC - Paris
   VI, 8, rue Buffon, 75005, Paris, France, France.
EM martin.pickford@mnhn.fr
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0177-0950
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Available name; Taxonomy; Animals and man;
   Documentation; Publications; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene;
   Palaeogene

DT Article
TI An evening bat (Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae) from the late Early Eocene
   of France, with comments on the antiquity of modern bats.
AU Hand, Suzanne J. (s.hand@unsw.edu.au) 
   Sige, Bernard
   Archer, Michael
   Black, Karen H.
SO Palaeovertebrata (Montpellier)
VL 40
IS 2
PS e2
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bats are among the most numerous and widespread mammals today, but their
   fossil record is comparatively meagre and their early evolution poorly
   understood. Here we describe a new fossil bat from dental remains
   recovered from late Early Eocene sediments at Premontre, northern
   France. This 50 million-year-old bat exhibits a mosaic of plesiomorphic
   and apomorphic dental features, including the presence of three lower
   premolars, a single-rooted p3, short p4 with metaconid, myotodont lower
   molars and a tall coronoid process of the dentary. This combination of
   features suggests it is an early member of Vespertilionidae, today's
   most speciose and geographically widespread bat family. The Premontre
   bat has bearing on hypotheses about the origins of vesper or evening
   bats (Family Vespertilionidae), as well as crown-group chiropterans.
C1 Hand, Suzanne J.; Univ New South Wales, Sch Biol Earth & Environm Sci,
   Sydney, NSW, 2052, Australia, Australia.
EM s.hand@unsw.edu.au
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0031-0247
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Premonycteris [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Premonycteris vesper [France /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Vespertilionidae [Origin of taxon /  / significance of new fossil taxon
   from France] [Zoogeography / Palaeozoogeography / ]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI A new species of Propalaeotherium (Palaeotheriidae, Perissodactyla,
   Mammalia) from the Middle Eocene locality of Aumelas (Herault, France).
AU Remy, Jean Albert (jean.a.remy@wanadoo.fr) 
   Krasovec, Gabriel
   Marandat, Bernard
SO Palaeovertebrata (Montpellier)
VL 40
IS 2
PS e1
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Propalaeotherium species, clearly distinct from the genus
   Eurohippus, is described. It is characterized by having a similar size
   as P. voigti from the German Geiseltal localities (MP 11 to MP 13
   reference-level), but differs in several features suggesting a slighty
   more derived morphology. It presents indeed less brachyodont crowns with
   less prominent and less elevated cingula, slightly larger relative
   surface of premolars, and a more marked metaconid splitting on cheek
   teeth. This new species is unknown from other European localities except
   the nearby Saint-Martin de Londres locality which has been considered
   older than the MP 13 level.

   Bataillon, Montpellier, F-34095, France, France.
EM jean.a.remy@wanadoo.fr

DT Article
TI New Occurrences of Fossil Macrocheira (Brachyura, Inachidae) from the
   North Eastern Pacific.
AU Nyborg, Torrey
   Nyborg, Brant
   Garassino, Alessandro
   Vega, Francisco J.
SO Paleontologia Mexicana
VL 5
IS 2
PS 123-135
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New specimens of the fossil Macrocheira collected from Eocene to Miocene
   rocks of Canada and western United States increase the fossil record of
   the Inachidae (MacLeay, 1838). Macrocheira is represented by only one
   extant species, M. kaempferi, endemic to Japan and Taiwan. Two fossil
   species have previously been described from Washington State: M.
   longirostra (Schweitzer and Feldmann, 1999), from the Eocene Quimper
   Sandstone, and M. teglandi (Rathbun, 1926), from the Oligocene Makah
   Formation. Three new species are reported: M. jayi n. sp. from the late
   Eocene to Oligocene Hesquiat Formation of Vancouver Island, British
   Columbia, Canada; M. sullivani n. sp. from the late Eocene to early
   Oligocene Keasey Formation of Oregon State, U.S.A.; and M columbiaensis
   n. sp. from the early to middle Miocene Astoria Formation of Washington
   State, U.S.A. Several Macrocheira species have also been reported from
   the Miocene of Japan; however, their systematic position is tenuous and
   therefore they are referred to as Macrocheira sp. aff. M. kaempferi.
   With the description of three new species of Macrocheira, the number of
   fossil species is increased to five and the genus is now well
   established in the North Eastern Pacific from the Eocene to Miocene.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 2007-5189
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Macrocheira columbiaensis [Washington /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ].
   
   Macrocheira jayi [British Columbia /  / new species] [Palaeogene /  / ].
   
   Macrocheira sullivani [Oregon /  / new species] [Palaeogene /  / ].

   131; Fossil].

   127; Fossil]. 
   Macrocheira sullivani (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Oregon, Palaeogene, P. 128;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species: Pilummede penderensis (Decapoda: Brachyura)
   from the Castle Hayne Limestone Formation (Eocene) of Pender County,
   North Carolina (USA).
AU Osso, Alex (aosso@comt.cat) 
   Clements, Don
SO Paleontologia Mexicana
VL 5
IS 2
PS 137-146
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Discovery of new material from two previously known outcrops in the
   Bartonian and Priabonian levels of the Castle Hayne Limestone Formation
   (Eocene) of Pender County (North Carolina, USA), permits the description
   of a new decapod genus and species, Pilummede penderensis, and the
   assignation to it of specimens from the same outcrops, hitherto
   described as Lessinicarcinus euglyphos. Even though some of the studied
   specimens exhibit dorsal carapaces exquisitely well-preserved, only
   little of ventral structures have been preserved, precluding a proper
   familial placement. Nevertheless, based on overall similarities, the new
   taxon is placed within Pilumnoidea with reservations. Comparisons with
   related forms show that the dorsal pattern of Pilummede penderensis is
   widely shared by a variety of fossil and extant decapod taxa.
C1 Osso, Alex; JV Foix 12H,1er 1a, Tarragona, Catalonia, 43007, Spain,
   Spain.
EM aosso@comt.cat
SC Zoology
SN 2007-5189

   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Pilummede penderensis [North Carolina /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404019861
DT Article
TI Silurian and Early Devonian Ostracods of the Severnaya Zemlya
   Archipelago.
AU Abushik, A.F.
   Evdokimova, I.O. (Irina_Evdokimova@vsegei.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 50
IS 7
PS 659-724
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Descriptions and images of reference associations (for formations) of
   the Silurian and Early Devonian ostracods from the Severnaya Zemlya
   Archipelago are provided for the first time. They include 105 ostracod
   taxa, including two new genera and 33 new species and substantially
   supplement the faunal characteristics of the Silurian and Early Devonian
   local stratigraphic units of the region. The Silurian and Early Devonian
   deposits of the Severnaya Zemlya Archipelago are correlated with the
   beds of adjacent regions of northern Eurasia; a number of reference
   levels for comparison of the Severnaya Zemlya strati-graphic scheme with
   the General Stratigraphic Scale are revealed. The material reported in
   the paper provides a detailed local stratigraphic scheme that increases
   the efficiency of prospecting and predictive works on hydrocarbons and
   solid minerals on the islands and shelf of the Kara Sea. The data
   provided are of interest for survey geologists, stratigraphers, experts
   in the Paleozoic beds.
C1 Evdokimova, I.O.; Karpinsky All Russia Res Geol Inst, Srednii Pr 74, St
   Petersburg, 199106, Russia, Russia.
EM Irina_Evdokimova@vsegei.ru

AN ZOOR15405025905
DT Article
TI Middle Aptian Biostratigraphy and Ammonoids of the Northern Caucasus and
   Transcaspia.
AU Bogdanova, T.N. (tnbogdanova@list.ru) 
   Mikhailova, I.A.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 50
IS 8
PS 725-933
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Middle Aptian deposits of the central and eastern regions of the
   Northern Caucasus and Transcaspia (Turkmenistan) are described and
   discussed, including the history of their studies, lithology, and
   characterization of ammonite zones in each region. Ammonites of the
   superfamilies Parahoplitoidea and Douvilleiceratoidea, which form the
   basis for the Middle Aptian stratigraphic framework, are discussed and
   their origin and taxonomic composition are briefly considered. Forty
   species of 12 genera and 5 families are described. The historical
   stratotype section of the Gargasian stage of the French Lower Cretaceous
   scale is discussed, including the history of its recognition and
   subsequent study, and its present state. The authors' concept of the
   tripartite subdivision of the Aptian Stage in the Russian Scale is
   substantiated. The Middle Aptian deposits are described in detail, and
   the range and zonal subdivision of the Middle Aptian France, Great
   Britain, Germany, and other regions of the world are discussed. The
   correlation of the Middle Aptian in the Boreal and Tethyan realms is
   given.
C1 Bogdanova, T.N.; Karpinsky All Russia Geol Res Inst, Srednii Pr 74, St
   Petersburg, 199106, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Paleontology and Stratigraphy of the Middle-Upper Miocene of the Taman
   Peninsula: Part 1. Description of Key Sections and Benthic Fossil
   Groups.
AU Popov, S.V. (serg.pop@mail.ru) 
   Rostovtseva, Yu. V.
   Fillippova, N. Yu.
   Golovina, L.A.
   Radionova, E.P.
   Goncharova, I.A.
   Vernyhorova, Yu. V.
   Dykan, N.I.
   Pinchuk, T.N.
   Iljina, L.B.
   Koromyslova, A.V.
   Kozyrenko, T.M.
   Nikolaeva, I.A.
   Viskova, L.A.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 50
IS 10
PS 1039-1206
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The Taman sections, reference for the Neogene of the Eastern Paratethys,
   are investigated thoroughly paleontologically and stratigraphically,
   with level-by-level description of four sections, correlated in detail
   with each other; fossil remains coming from them are examined
   conjointly, with uniform binding to the sections. The composition of
   malacofaunas and foraminifers allowed the recognition of all regional
   stages and substages from the Upper Chokrakian to Middle Kimmerian,
   their boundaries, and correlation with the Kerch stratotypes. The study
   of the taxonomic composition of ostracods improved the boundaries of
   strati- graphic ranges of particular species. The complete and
   continuous sequence of Karaganian-Konkian deposits has provided the data
   improving the volume and boundaries of the Konkian Regional Stage and
   showing that it is divided into three units. Investigation of these
   groups provided the stratigraphical basis for pioneer studies of
   phytoplankton; the taxonomic composition and distribution in the
   sections of nannoplankton, diatoms, and organic-walled phytoplankton are
   investigated completely for the first time; the points of penetration of
   marine water into the basin are recognized. The most reliable tool for
   correlation of deposits in a semi-closed basin is distribution of
   "ecologically plastic" groups that are able to tolerate a wide range of
   salinity and variation of the gas regime, such as mollusks, benthic
   foraminifers, and, among phytoplankton, diatoms and dinocysts. The
   appearance of stratigraphically significant diatom and nannoplankton
   species in Konkian, Sarmatian, and Maeotian deposits allowed the
   comparison of intervals of their presence with the oceanic zones where
   these index species are provided with absolute dating. The
   level-by-level palynological characteristics of the beds is reported,
   providing the basis for reconstruction of climatic changes in this
   region.

   spiriferid and spiriferinid genera from the Devonian of the East

DT Article
TI On the presence of Leda mendax Meneghini in Appelius, 1871 in the marine
   Pliocene-Pleistocene series of Romagna and description of Yoldiella
   ragazzinii n. sp. (Mollusca Bivalvia Protobranchia Nuculanidae,
   Yoldiidae).
FT Sulla presenza di Leda mendax Meneghini in Appelius, 1871 nella serie
   marina plio-pleistocenica romagnola e descrizione di Yoldiella
   ragazzinii n. sp. (Mollusca Bivalvia Protobranchia Nuculanidae,
   Yoldiidae).
AU Tabanelli, Cesare (cetabanelli@racine.ra.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 44
PS 1-14
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The discovery of a juvenile specimen of true Portlandia (Dyolia) mendax
   (Meneghini in Appelius, 1871) in Pliocene clays from Capocolle
   (Forli-Cesena province, Italy) hosted in Ruggieri collection (the Civic
   Museum of Natural Science of Faenza), has shown that the 'specimens
   previously identified by the author as Yoldia mendax in fact belong to a
   new species herein described as Yoldiella ragazzinii n. sp. The genus
   Dyolia La Perna R. & Ragaini L., 2008 is proposed as a subgenus of
   Portlandia Morch, 1857. Portlandia (Dyolia) mendax was considered up to
   now as a Pleistocene "cold species" endemic to the Mediterranean basin,
   nevertheless records of that species from Lower Pliocene clays in
   Piedmont suggest a much wider chronostratigraphy.

TI Microstelma sophiae a fossil new species from the Pliocenic limestone of
   Romagna, known as 'spungone' (Mollusca Gastropoda Rissoidea Zebinidae).
FT Microstelma sophiae nuova specie fossile dal calcare pliocenico

AU Gardella, Franco (franco.gardella@gmail.com)

SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 44
PS 15-19
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The authors report the discovery of a fossil specimen that can be
   assigned to the genus Microstelma A. Adams, 1863, from the Pliocene
   limestone of Romagna. It differs morphologically from all known species,
   both current and fossil. Due to its peculiar characters, it is proposed
   as a new species and described as Microstelma sophiae n. sp.

DT Article
TI Hestiasula brachyptera sp. nov. from SE India (Insecta Mantodea
   Hymenopodidae).
FT Descrizione di Hestiasula brachyptera sp. nov. dell'India del Sud-Est
   (Insecta Mantodea Hymenopodidae).
AU Villani, Marco (villanimarco@email.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 44
PS 93-103
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Mantodea, Hestiasula brachyptera sp. nov. is described,
   based on some specimens from south-east India. This species, new to
   science although already known to amateur breeders, is a little bit like
   other species of the genus Hestiasula Saussure, 1871, but differs by the
   development of the head apophysis and the short wings of females. The
   taxonomy of the genus is discussed on the basis of the principal
   morphological characters. The diagnosis of the new species and the
   identification key to the species of India are provided both in Italian
   and in English.

PT J
AN ZOOR15606038208
DT Article
TI First record of the genus Phyllorhiza spp. (Cnidaria; Scyphozoa,
   Mastigiidae) in the coastal waters of Malaysia.
AU Maghsoudlou, Elham (maghsoudlou.elham@gmail.com) 
   Yahya, Khairun
   Kwang, SimYee
   Azizah, Mohd Nor Siti
SO Research in Marine Sciences
VL 1
IS 1
PS 22-34
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This study employed two mitochondrial markers, 16S rRNA and cytochrome c
   oxidase I (COI) for species identification and resolved the taxonomic
   and systematic as well as population genetics of Phyllorhiza spp. in the
   coastal waters of Malaysia. A total number of 65 individuals sampled
   from three locations representing the three regions fringing the
   coastline. Phylogenetic trees constructed using Mega 5.0 software and
   Kimura 2-parameter with 1000 bootstrap replication were used to test
   reliability. The molecular data in complement with morphological
   differentiation revealed, at least three different species for the genus
   Phyllorhiza, Phyllorhiza punctata inhabit the coasts of Peninsular
   Malaysia while Phyllorhiza sp. 2 and Phyllorhiza sp. 3 which were only
   observed in East Peninsular Malaysia. The results of the current study
   also highlighted that colour alone is not sufficient for species
   differentiation of Phyllorhiza spp. The blue morphotype of Phyllorhiza
   sp. 1 observed in East Peninsular Malaysia was genetically identical to
   the brown morphotype observed in Northwest of Peninsular and recognised
   as P. punctata while the presence of Phyllorhiza sp. 2 and Phyllorhiza
   sp. 3 have never been recorded before in Malaysia. Consequently,
   understanding the taxonomy of local and invasive jellyfishes are
   necessary requirements for their management.
C1 Maghsoudlou, Elham; Univ Sains Malaysia, Ctr Marine & Coastal Studies
   CEMACS, Minden, Penang, 11800, Malaysia, Malaysia.
EM maghsoudlou.elham@gmail.com
RI Nor, Siti Azizah Mohd/A-8275-2011
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 2538-5542; 2538-2705
BD General morphology; Genetics; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Phyllorhiza; Phyllorhiza punctata [General morphology /  / new record;
   systematics] [Molecular genetics / Mt markers / ] [Population genetics /
    / ] [North Indian Ocean / Malaysia / ] [North Pacific /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Scyphozoa, Scyphomedusae
OR Phyllorhiza (Scyphomedusae): [New record]. 
   Phyllorhiza punctata (Scyphomedusae): [New record].

AN ZOOR15503017697
DT Article
TI DETECTION AND ISOLATION OF CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS FROM FIELD COLLECTED AEDES
   ALBOPICTUS SKUSE IN SELECTED SITES, PENINSULAR MALAYSIA.
AU Rozilawati, H. (rozilawati@imr.gov.my) 
   Masri, Mohd S.
   Zairi, J.
   Yahaya, M.A.
   Nazni, W.A.
   Lee, H.L.
SO Serangga
VL 21
IS 2
PS 171-181
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Chikungunya fever, an Aedes borne viral disease, is becoming a serious
   public health concern today since the first reported outbreak in Port
   Klang in 1998/99. Recently, more outbreaks were reported in Malaysia.
   Entomological investigations were conducted in Chikungunya virus cases
   localities in Peninsular Malaysia which cover Johor, Negeri Sembilan,
   Melaka, Perak, Pahang and Selangor state in order to identify the vector
   responsible for transmitting the Chikungunya virus. The adult mosquitoes
   were collected using modified aspirator and sweep net methods, whereas
   water holding containers were inspected for larvae. Reverse
   transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) were used as the
   detection of the virus. Positive samples were inoculated on the cell to
   isolate the virus. The most common species collected at the localities
   was Aedes albopictus followed by Culex quinquefasciatus, Aedes aegypti
   and Armigeres sp. Five pools (n=78) of female, adult Aedes albopictus
   collected from Tangkak, Johor were positive for the Chikungunya virus as
   detected by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. Three
   isolates were obtained and grouped with Central/East African genotype.
   The presence of Chikungunya virus in wild Aedes albopictus indicated
   that this mosquito is the most likely vector responsible for the
   transmission of virus to humans in Johor during the outbreak.
C1 Rozilawati, H.; Inst Med Res, IDRC, Jalan Pahang, Kuala Lumpur, 50588,
   Malaysia, Malaysia.
EM rozilawati@imr.gov.my
SC Infectious Diseases; Zoology
SN 1394-5130
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Transmission; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aedes albopictus [Transmission of viruses / Chikungunya virus /
   Prevalence; transmission risks] [Malaysia / Peninsular Malaysia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Culicidae
OR Aedes albopictus (Culicidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15503017697
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15404023161
DT Article
TI A multi-ootaxic assemblage from the Lower Cretaceous of the Cameros
   Basin (La Rioja; Northern Spain).
AU Moreno-Azanza, Miguel (mmazanza@fct.unl.pt) 
   Gasca, Jose Manuel
   Diaz-Martinez, Ignacio
   Lazaro, Blanca Bauluz
   Sanagustin, Jose Ignacio Canudo
   Fernandez, Arturo
   Perez-Lorente, Felix
SO Spanish Journal of Palaeontology
VL 31
IS 2
PS 305-320
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Here we describe the new fossil site of El Itorcajo in the vicinity of
   Trevijano (La Rioja, Spain). It is located in the palustrine facies of
   the Enciso Group (Cameros Basin). This new locality has provided dozens
   of eggshell fragments, together with other vertebrate remains and
   charophyte fructifications, which allow dating of the locality as
   Valanginian-Hauterivian. Five ootaxa have being recognized: 1) the
   Spheroolithidae Guegoolithus turolensis; 2) a surprisingly thick
   Prismatoolithidae indet., with certain affinities to the oogenus
   Sankata, that may represent a new oogenus and oospecies for this
   oofamily; 3) the Krokolithidae Krokolithes sp.; 4) recrystallized
   ?Testudoolithidae eggshells; and 5) ?Geckoolithidae eggshells of
   uncertain affinity. This oodiversity is similar to that of other
   eggshell microsites. The ootaxonomic list differs from the other Iberian
   locality of the same age, Pochancalo 1 (Villanueva de Iluerva Formation,
   Zaragoza) in lacking sauropod and megalosauroid theropod eggshells, but
   shares the presence the ornithopod and coelurosaurian theropod eggshells
   with other younger microsites found in similar facies. The age of the
   new locality has immediate consequences for the tectono-sedimentary
   framework of the Cameros Basin, and the new data will need to be
   considered in future stratigraphical works. Furthermore, the reliability
   of eggshells as biostratigraphic markers is questioned, and the
   viability of Guegoolithus as a guide fossil for the lower Barremian is
   rejected.
C1 Moreno-Azanza, Miguel; Univ Nova Lisboa, Geobiotec, Caparica, P-2829526,
   Portugal, Portugal.
EM mmazanza@fct.unl.pt
RI Bauluz Lazaro, Blanca/N-9802-2018
OI Bauluz Lazaro, Blanca/0000-0002-4970-6333
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Paleontology
SN 2255-0550

   ] [Cretaceous / Lower Cretaceous / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404023162
DT Article
TI Analysis of the Iberian Aragonian record of Paleotestudo, and refutation
   of the validity of the Spanish 'Testudo catalaunica' and the French
   'Paleotestudo canetotiana'.
AU Perez-Garcia, Adan (paleontologo@gmail.com) 
SO Spanish Journal of Palaeontology
VL 31
IS 2
PS 321-340
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Information about the small Testudinidae taxon or taxa (i.e. with a
   length less than 30 cm) recorded in the Aragonian of the Iberian
   Peninsula was, until now, very limited. The references to 'Paleotestudo
   catalaunica' were regarded as possibly the only valid systematic
   identifications. That species corresponds to a tortoise defined in the
   Aragonian of Spain (Sant Quirze del Valles, Barcelona). New material of
   tortoises, from several Spanish Aragonian regions, is analyzed here. The
   specimens from the type locality of 'Paleotestudo catalaunica' and from
   other Spanish sites, as well as those from two other European late
   Aragonian sites (Sansan in France and Hohenhowen in Germany, where two
   taxa represented by several specimens were described) are reviewed here.
   This study refutes the validity of the taxa described in Sant Quirze del
   Valles and in Sansan, being recognized as junior synonyms of the German
   Paleotestudo antique. This species is the only one recognized in the
   Aragonian of Spain.
C1 Perez-Garcia, Adan; UNED, Fac Ciencias, Paseo Senda del Rey 9, Madrid,
   28040, Spain, Spain.
EM paleontologo@gmail.com
RI Perez Garcia, Adan/I-3114-2015
OI Perez Garcia, Adan/0000-0002-9074-6855
SC Zoology
SN 2255-0550

   region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Testudinidae [Europe /  / systematics] [Miocene / Aragonian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Cryptodira, Testudinidae
OR Testudinidae (Cryptodira): [Fossil]. 
   Paleotestudo antiqua - (Bronn 1831) (Testudinidae): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 336; Syn nov, Paleotestudo canetotiana, p. 337; Syn nov, Paleotestudo
   catalaunica (Bataller 1926), p. 337].

AN ZOOR15404023166
DT Article
TI A new estiracostern dinosaur (Ornithopoda: Ankylopollexia) from the
   Lower Cretaceous of Spain.
FT Un nuevo dinosaurio estiracosterno (Ornithopoda: Ankylopollexia) del
   Cretacico Inferior de Espana.
AU Fuentes Vidart, Carolina (carolfuentes@ono.com) 
   Calvo, Manuel Meijide
   Meijide Fuentes, Federico
   Meijide Fuentes, Manuel
SO Spanish Journal of Palaeontology
VL 31
IS 2
PS 407-446
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Zorralbo 1 site from the Lower Cretaceous (upper Hauterivian/lower
   Barremian of the Golmayo Formation), located in Golmayo municipality
   (Soria, Spain), has yielded diverse material belonging to four types of
   dinosaurs: omithopods, ankylosaurids (Polacanthus sp.), sauropods
   (Titanosauriform) and theropods (Allosauroidea and Dromaeosauridae),
   crocodiles (Goniopholis sp.) and an undetermined turtle. In this paper,
   we analyze die material belonging to a new iguanodontian dinosaur, a
   medium-sized quadrupedal specimen (9-10 m long) weighing three tonnes,
   that exhibits a number of morphological and biometric features that set
   it apart from already known iguanodontians: 1) the coronoid process is a
   prolongation of the dentary, being the last dental alveolus in front the
   coronoid process instead of at its base; 2) the length of the scapula is
   six times its distal width and seven times its minimum width; 3) the
   acromial process is facing the posterior protuberance; 4) in the
   humerus, the inner tuberosity is not aligned with the ulnar condyle and
   the radial condyle sits above the unlar condyle; 5) in the ulna, the
   distal end is wider than the proximal end and it is mace-shaped; 6) in
   the radius, the distal end is also mace-shaped; 7) the carpus is made up
   of three components (carpals 1, 11 and III, radiale and intermediale)
   (ulnare and carpal IV) (carpal V); 8) the phalangeal formula is 1-3-3-2-
   (3-4); the width of the wrist is equivalent to 70 % of the hand length;
   9) straight prepubis without distal widening or grooves and in die base
   of the post-pubic ramus, the obturator foramen is open and semi-covered
   by a mesial flat bone plate. The combination of these features and the
   differences between this specimen and all other iguanodontian genera to
   which it has been compared lead to the conclusion that it is indeed a
   new genus within this dinosaur group. We propose the name Magnamanus
   soriaensis nov. gen. nov. sp.
C1 Fuentes Vidart, Carolina; C Almazan 17, Soria, 42004, Spain, Spain.
EM carolfuentes@ono.com
SC Zoology
SN 2255-0550
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Magnamanus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Magnamanus soriaensis [Spain /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Ornithopoda
OR Magnamanus (Ornithopoda): [Gen nov, Of subgroup Styracosterna, Type
   species Magnamanus soriaensis, p. 411, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Magnamanus soriaensis (Ornithopoda): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 411;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15403010468
DT Article
TI CERITHIOPSIDAE and NEWTONIELLIDAE (GASTROPODA: TRIPHOROIDEA) from New
   Caledonia, Western Pacific.
AU Cecalupo, Alberto (acecalupo@gmail.com) 
   Perugia, Ivan
SO Visaya
SU 7
PS 5-175
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present regional monograph is based on the study of 4,859 specimens
   of CERITHIOPSIDAE and NEWTONIELLIDAE collected during several
   expeditions in New Caledonia and the Loyalty Islands. Altogether, 171
   species are present, of which 76 are new to science; the range of 92
   already known species is expanded; 3 species are figured but not named.
   The generic allocation of a number of species remains uncertain, a
   situation that can be resolved only with the analysis of the soft parts.
   All species are described and illustrated with digital color photos and
   with environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM); particular
   emphasis was given to protoconchs. Fifteen genera of CERITHIOPSIDAE are
   represented: Belonimorphis (1 species), Cerithiopsidella (1),
   Clathropsis (22), Horologica (22), Joculator (41), Marshallopsis (12),
   Mendax (5), Onchodia (1), Prolixodens (10), Retilaskeya (1), Sella (3),
   Specula (16), Sundaya (7), Synthopsis (18), Tubercliopsis (3); and 2
   genera of NEWTONIELLIDAE: Ataxocerithium (2), Cerithiella (6). We also
   analyzed the species from Lifou and Uvea (Loyalty Is.) instituted by
   Melvill & Standen (1896).
C1 Cecalupo, Alberto; Acquario & Civ Stn Idrobiol Milano, Viale Gadio 2,
   Milan, MI, I-20121, Italy, Italy.
EM acecalupo@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR15211070559
DT Article
TI A remarkable brachyceran fly (Diptera: Tabanomorpha) from Late
   Cretaceous Burmese amber.
AU Zhang, Qingqing
   Zhang, Junfeng
   Wang, Bo (bowang@nigpas.ac.cn) 
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 1-7
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 19
AB A new brachyceran fly (Diptera: Tabanomorpha), Pseudorhagio zhangi gen.
   et sp. nov., is described from Late Cretaceous Burmese amber. It is
   tentatively placed as Family incertae sedis in Tabanomorpha and
   distinguished from other Tabanomorpha by the following unusual
   combination of characters: head wider than thorax; body densely covered
   with fine and short setae, devoid of macrosetae; scutum strongly convex,
   nearly spherical; scutellum rather small, convex; antenna) flagellum
   elongated, tapering, unsegmented; vein R4 perpendicular to R5, and
   strongly curved; crossvein m-m very long, strongly sinuated; tibial spur
   formula 0, 2, 0. This discovery further confirms the high diversity of
   Tabanomorpha in Late Cretaceous Burmese amber. An updated list of
   brachyceran species in Burmese amber is given. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
   All rights reserved.
C1 Wang, Bo; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, 39 East
   Beijing Rd, Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.
EM bowang@nigpas.ac.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0195-6671
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Brachycera [Checklists / Updated checklist / Taxa from Burmese amber]
   [Myanmar /  / ] [Cretaceous / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
   Pseudorhagio [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Pseudorhagio zhangi [Myanmar /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera
OR Brachycera (Diptera): [Fossil]. 
   Pseudorhagio (Brachycera): [Gen nov, Of infraorder Tabanomorpha, family
   incertae sedis, Type species Pseudorhagio zhangi, p. 3, Cretaceous;
   Fossil]. 
   Pseudorhagio zhangi (Brachycera): [Sp nov, Myanmar, Cretaceous, P. 3,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15211070559
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15211070561
DT Article
TI New data on Early Cretaceous odonatans (Stenophlebiidae, Aeschnidiidae)
   from northern China.
AU Zheng, Daran (dranzheng@gmail.com) 
   Wang, He
   Jarzembowski, Edmund A.
   Wang, Bo
   Chang, Su-Chin
   Zhang, Haichun
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 59-65
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 23
AB Liaostenophlebia yixianensis gen. et sp. nov., a new stenophlebiid
   damsel-dragonfly, is described from the Lower Cretaceous Yixian
   Formation of western Liaoning, northern China. It is the third Chinese
   damsel dragonfly belonging to the family Stenophlebiidae to be
   described. Liaostenophlebia gen. nov. differs from the other genera of
   Stenophlebiidae in having Ax2 shifted just above MAb, a transverse and
   narrow Hal, a more curved anterior side of the hypertriangle, and a
   broader cubital-anal area. Sinostenophlebia zhanjiakouensis Hong, 1984
   was previously attributed to Stenophlebiidae and hardly compares with
   other genera within this family. A check of the plates of the type
   species (Sinostenophlebia zhanjiakouensis Hong, 1984) suggests that
   Sinostenophlebia Hong, 1984 should be a member of the family
   Aeschnidiidae and it is very likely that this genus is a junior synonym
   of Leptaeschnidium Pritykina, 1977. The new data increases the diversity
   of both Stenophlebiidae and Aeschnidiidae in the Lower Cretaceous of
   China. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Zheng, Daran; Univ Hong Kong, Dept Earth Sci, Hong Kong, Hong Kong,
   China, China.
EM dranzheng@gmail.com

DT Article
TI New pelecinid wasps (Hymenoptera: Pelecinidae) from Upper Cretaceous
   Myanmar amber.
AU Guo, Lichao
   Shih, Chungkun
   Li, Longfeng
   Ren, Dong (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 84-90
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB A new genus with a new species, Brachypelecinus euthyntus gen. et sp.
   nov., and two new species, Abropelecinus tytthus sp. nov. and
   Zoropelecinus periosus sp. nov., are described and figured from three
   exquisitely preserved pelecinid wasps in the Upper Cretaceous Myanmar
   (Burma) amber. These taxa, owing to their well-preserved characters in
   amber, provide a better understanding of morphological changes and
   relationships among the constituent groups, while further highlighting
   the diversity of Pelecinidae in the Mesozoic. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All
   rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Revision of Cenomanian regular echinoids in collections at the Cairo
   Geological Museum, Egypt.
AU El Qot, Gamal M. (g_elgot@hotmail.com) 
   Abdelhamid, Marouf A.
   Abdelghany, Medhat S.
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 91-125
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 14
AB Cenomanian rocks of Egypt are rich in moderately to well-preserved
   echinoids. From the, large Cretaceous echinoid collection at the Cairo
   Geological Museum, a total of 27 regular species, in 12 genera, eight
   families, six orders and two subclasses, are revised and systematically
   described from these strata as exposed at several localities in Egypt.
   One new family (Pedinopsidae), one new subfamily (Lorioliinae), one new
   genus (Alternocidaris) and two new species of Goniopygus, G. subaequalis
   (Gebel Ekma) and G. macrotuberculatus (Gebel El Minsherah), are erected.
   Additionally, two species of Diplopodia, D. micropyga Fourtau, 1921 and
   D. halperti Fourtau, 1921, are transferred to the genus Pedinopsis. (C)
   2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 El Qot, Gamal M.; Benha Univ, Fac Sci, POB 13518, Benha, Egypt, Egypt.

DT Article
TI Burmadysagrioninae, a new subfamily (Odonata: Zygoptera: Dysagrionidae)
   from mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber.
AU Zheng, Daran (dranzheng@gmail.com) 
   Wang, Bo
   Jarzembowski, Edmund A.
   Chang, Su-Chin
   Nel, Andre
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 126-132
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB A new subfamily, Burmadysagrioninae Zheng, Wang and Nel, subfam. nov.,
   for the genus and species Burmadysagrion zhangi Zheng, Wang and Nel,
   gen. et sp. nov. is described from mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber. This is
   the third dysagrionid damselfly from the Mesozoic and the second one
   from Burmese amber. The new specimen has a unique discoidal cell with
   the anterior and posterior sides not parallel, and the basal side longer
   than the distal side, unlike the typical 'sieblosiid-dysagrionine' type.
   It differs from other dysagrionid damselflies by the presence of a
   simple wing venation, the vein IR1 originating below the pterostigma and
   a special discoidal cell. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Zheng, Daran; Univ Hong Kong, Dept Earth Sci, Hong Kong, Hong Kong,
   China, China.
EM dranzheng@gmail.com
OI Zheng, Daran/0000-0003-0520-6780

SN 0195-6671

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Burmadysagrioninae [Cretaceous /  / New subfamily].

DT Article
TI First record of the family Scolebythidae (Hymenoptera) in mid-Cretaceous
   amber from Myanmar.
AU Cockx, Pierre F.D.
   McKellar, Ryan C. (ryan.mckellar@gov.sk.ca) 
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 133-139
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Two new genera and species belonging to the family Scolebythidae are
   described from mid -Cretaceous amber of Myanmar, Cursoribythus
   silvestris and Siccibythus musculosus. These taxa are introduced into
   the current phylogenetic tree of the family, in order to analyze their
   relationships and observe their impacts on our understanding of the
   family. The implication of the findings (this is the first record of the
   family in the Cretaceous amber deposits of Myanmar) are discussed. (C)
   2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Lidryopinae, new byrrhid subfamily from the Lower Cretaceous of France
   (Coleoptera, Byrrhidae).
AU Kirejtshuk, Alexander G. (agk@zin.ru) 
   Nel, Andre
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 67
PS 140-147
PD Dec 1 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 2
U2 16
AB The byrrhid subfamily Lidryopinae subfam. nov. is proposed for Lidryops
   occultus gen. et sp. nov. described from Lower Cretaceous "opaque" amber
   originated from Archingeay-Les Nouillers, Charente Maritime, southwest
   France which was studied using propagation phase contrast X-ray
   synchrotron microtomography at the European Synchrotron Radiation
   Facility (Grenoble). This byrrhid subfamily differs from members of the
   closely related groups (Chelonariidae, Limnichidae, Dryopidae, Elmidae,
   Lutrochidae) in the set of characters including the moderately convex
   dorsuria, the subpectinate antennae, the five-segmented tarsi with
   strongly lobed tarsomeres 1-4, subsecuriform ultimate maxillary and
   labial palpomeres. An assumption on probable lifestyle of Lidryops
   occultus gen. et sp. nov. is proposed on the basis of structural
   peculiarities. A short review of the byrrhid fossil record and its
   analysis are made. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Kirejtshuk, Alexander G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Emb 1,
   St Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM agk@zin.ru

SN 0195-6671

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Jurassic /  / ]. 
   Lidryopinae [Cretaceous /  / New subfamily]. 
   Lidryops [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Lidryops occultus [France /  / new species; Described from amber]

   species Lidryops occultus, p. 142, Cretaceous; Fossil].

AB Three new species of scutacarid mites (Acari: Pygmephoroidea:
   Scutacaridae), Imparipes tomentosussp. nov., Scutacarus
   flexisetosimilissp. nov., and S. aequalissp. nov. are newly described

   (Acari: Scutacaridae) is provided.

DT Article
TI On the identity of Neoseiulus fallacis (Garman 1948) (Parasitiformes,
   Phytoseiidae): redescription of the species and description of the new
   species Neoseiulus garmani.
AU Tsolakis, Haralabos (haralabos.tsolakis@unipa.it) 
   Ragusa, Salvatore
SO International Journal of Acarology
VL 42
IS 8
PS 394-404
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 22
AB Neoseiulus fallacis (Garman) is a broadly commercialised phytoseiid mite
   used in Integrated Pest Management (IPM) programmes especially in
   northern and southern America. However, its taxonomic status was, until
   now, equivocal because no redescription based on type material had ever
   been made. The authors redescribe N. fallacis from type material in
   Garman's collection, designating the lectotype and paralectotypes for
   the species. Moreover, a new species of the fallacis complex, discovered
   among the fallacis type material, is described and named N. garmanisp.
   nov. in honour of Philip Garman.
C1 Tsolakis, Haralabos; Univ Palermo, Dept Agr & Forest Sci, Palermo,
   Italy, Italy.
EM haralabos.tsolakis@unipa.it
SC Zoology
SN 0164-7954
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Neoseiulus garmani [Connecticut /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Iphidulus fallacis - Garman 1948 (Acari): [Lectotype designated, P.
   398]. 
   Neoseiulus fallacis - (Garman 1948) (Acari): [Redescription, P. 399]. 
   Neoseiulus fallacis complex (Acari): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 403]. 
   Neoseiulus garmani (Acari): [Sp nov, Connecticut, P. 401].

TI Two new species of Austrophthiracarus (Acari: Oribatida: Phthiracaridae)
   from Capleston Biological Reserve in New Zealand.
AU Liu, Dong
   Wu, Donghui (wudonghui@iga.ac.cn) 
SO International Journal of Acarology
VL 42
IS 8
PS 416-419
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB In this study, two new species of Austrophthiracarus (Oribatida:
   Phthiracaridae) from Capleston Biological Reserve, New Zealand,
   Austrophthiracarus paracronadunsp. nov. and Austrophthiracarus
   vestigiussp. nov., are described and illustrated. A new name
   Austrophthiracarus neonominatus is proposed for the species
   Austrophthiracarus parapulchellus Niedbala, 2016. An updated key to all
   known species of Austrophthiracarus in New Zealand is provided.

TI KNIPOWITSCHIATREMA STERNULAI SP.N (TREMATODA: HETEROPHYIDAE) IN STERNULA
   ALBIFRONS (LITTLE TERN) (AVES: LARIDAE) OF HYDERABAD, SINDH, PAKISTAN.
AU Bushra, S.
   Das Sanjota, N. (drsanjota2@gmail.com) 
   Ghazi, R.R.
   Khan, Aly
SO Flora and Fauna - Jhansi
VL 22
IS 1
PS 69-75
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Knipowitschiatrema stemulai sp. nov. is described from the intestine of
   a bird Sternula albifrons (Little tern). The new species is
   characterized by having: smaller body size, a short pre-pharynx, 1st
   quarter position of acetabulum, elongated seminal vesicle, saccular with
   narrow anterior portion, situated far below the acetabulum, roughly
   spherical ovary, size of testes, commencement of vitelline follicles
   from level of testes and smaller size of eggs.
C1 Das Sanjota, N.; Karachi Univ Campus, Southern Zone Agr Res Ctr,
   Karachi, 75270, Pakistan, Pakistan.
EM drsanjota2@gmail.com

TI MORPHOTAXONOMICAL STUDY OF A NEW CESTODE GANGESIA (GANGESIA) CHOPARAI
   N.SP. FROM A FRESH WATER FISH, WALLAGO ATTU FROM JALAUN (U.P.) INDIA.
AU Pathak, Alok
   Srivastav, A.K. (akscks@rediffmail.com) 
SO Flora and Fauna - Jhansi
VL 22
IS 1
PS 115-120
PD Dec 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The worm was procured from intestine of fresh water fish, Wallago attu
   at Ragaulai, Distict Jalaun, Uttar Pradesh, India. After morphological
   study Of worm we reach on the conclusion that present species differs
   from all known species of genus Gangesia in the presence of internal
   seminal vesical, uterus 3-7 diverticula on either side and other
   characters.

   India, India.

   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India

DT Article
TI A New Replacement Name for a Homonymy, an Additional Species to Japanese
   Fauna, and Correction of Errors to the Entiminae in 'The Insects of
   Japan, Vols. 3 & 4' (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Entiminae).
AU Morimoto, Katsura (morimotok@jcom.home.ne.jp) 
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 147-148
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new replacement name, Trachyphilus yasuoi Morimoto, nom nov. is given
   for 56 Trachyphilus takakurai Morimoto, 2015 (The Insects of Japan, Vol.
   4: 436, not 19 T. takakurai Morimoto, 1. c.: 398) due to homonymy. First
   record of Otiorhynchus cribricollis Gyllenhal, 1834 is made in Entiminae
   of Japan upon a female from Ashigawa-son,Yamanashi Pref. Torishimazo
   kawashitai Morimoto, 2015 was described on two females from Anijima I.
   in Ogasawara Isls., and its generic position is confirmed by dissecting
   the additional males upon the aedeagal characters. Corrections are also
   notified for some errors in the Insects of Japan, Vols. 3 (2006) and 4
   (2015).
C1 Morimoto, Katsura; 20-101 Natadanchi,Higashi Ku, Fukuoka, 8110205,
   Japan, Japan.
EM morimotok@jcom.home.ne.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Available name; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Asphalmus chofuensis [Japan /  / Distribution]. 
   Entiminae [Faunal works / Insects of Japan volumes 3 & 4 / Corrections]
   [Japan /  / ]. 
   Otiorhynchus (Arammichnus) cribricollis [Japan /  / New record;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Asphalmus chofuensis (Curculionidae). 
   Entiminae (Curculionidae). 
   Otiorhynchus (Arammichnus) cribricollis - Gyllenhal 1834
   (Curculionidae): [New record]. 
   Torishimazo kawashitai - Morimoto (Curculionidae): [First time
   described, Male, p. 148]. 
   Trachyphilus takakurai - Morimoto 2015 (Curculionidae): [Preoccupied
   name replaced by, Trachyphilus yasuoi, p. 147]. 
   Trachyphilus yasuoi (Curculionidae): [Nom nov, For Trachyphilus
   takakurai Morimoto 2015, p. 147].

TI Eighty-nine Replacement Names for Braconidae and Ichneumonidae (Insecta:
   Hymenoptera: Ichneumonoidea).
AU Kittel, Rebecca N. (rebecca.n.Kittel@gmail.com) 
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 161-174
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New replacement names are proposed for one genus and 15 species within
   the subfamilies Alysiinae, Aphidiinae, Cenocoeliinae, Cheloninae,
   Doryctinae, Euphorinae, Gnamptodontinae, Macrocentrinae, Microgastrinae,
   Orgilinae, and Rogadinae in the Braconidae and one genus and 72 species
   within the subfamilies Banchinae, Campopleginae, Cremastinae, Cryptinae,
   Ichneumoninae, Mesochorinae, Orthocentrinae, Pimplinae, and Tryphoninae
   in the Ichneumonidae.

PT J
AN ZOOR15306037999
DT Article
TI A New Species of the Subgenus Tripodura (Diptera: Chironomidae:
   Polypedilum) from Yaeyama Islands, Japan.
AU Yamamoto, Nao (nao53210@plant.osakafu-u.ac.jp) 
   Yamamoto, Masaru
   Hirowatari, Toshiya
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 191-194
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Polypedilum (Tripodura) nudigracile sp. n. is described from Iriomote
   Island, Japan. The species is closely similar to P. (T.) nudiprostatum
   Zhang et Wang, 2006 in many aspects, but distinguished from the latter
   by the trilobate anal point, hairy lateral projections on both sides of
   the anal point and the superior volsella without microtrichia. Some
   species groups sense Vardal et al. (2002) related to the present species
   are briefly discussed.
C1 Yamamoto, Nao; Osaka Prefecture Univ, Grad Sch Life & Environm Sci,
   Nakaku Gakuen Cho 1-1, Sakai, Osaka, 5998531, Japan, Japan.
EM nao53210@plant.osakafu-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Polypedilum (Tripodura) nudigracile [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Chironomidae
OR Polypedilum (Tripodura) nudigracile (Chironomidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P.
   191]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15306037999
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15306038000
DT Article
TI Erection of a New Subgenus in the genus Polypedilum Kieffer, 1912
   (Diptera: Chironomidae) from Japan.
AU Yamamoto, Nao (nao53210@plant.osakafu-u.ac.jp) 
   Yamamoto, Masaru
   Hirowatari, Toshiya
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 195-197
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New subgeus Atopipedilum is erected for Polypedilum notabile Yamamoto,
   Yamamoto et Hirowatari, 2012 from Yeyama Islands, Japan. This subgenus
   is distinguished from any other subgenera by the unique structure of the
   superior volsella, which has a long microtrichiose dorsal lobe
   originating from the base to apical 3/4 of the projection. Furthermore,
   one more unique character state is appeared in the bifurcated pulvilli
   which are quite different from other species within the genus
   Polypedilum in the basic structure. Key to subgenera for males is
   provided.
C1 Yamamoto, Nao; Osaka Prefecture Univ, Grad Sch Life & Environm Sci,
   Nakaku Gakuen Cho 1-1, Sakai, Osaka, 5998531, Japan, Japan.
EM nao53210@plant.osakafu-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Taxonomy; Key
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Chironomidae
OR Polypedilum - Kieffer 1912 (Chironomidae): [Key to subgenera, Male
   imagines, p. 196]. 
   Polypedilum (Atopipedilum) (Chironomidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Polypedilum notabile Yamamoto, Yamamoto et Hirowatari 2012, p. 195]. 
   Polypedilum notabile - Yamamoto, Yamamoto et Hirowatari 2012
   (Chironomidae): [Designated type species for new subgenus, Polypedilum
   (Atopipedilum), p. 195].

TI A Note of the Genus Ziaelas (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae, Amarygmini) with
   a Description of a New Species from the Southern Part of Vietnam.
AU Masumoto, Kimio
   Lee, Chi-Feng
   Akita, Katsumi
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 209-213
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Ziaelas is dealt with. Two known species were re-examined and
   Z. formosanus Hozawa was confirmed as a good species. A new species, Z.
   fujiokai sp. nov., is described from the southern part of Vietnam. A
   diagnosis table for the members of the genus Ziaelas is presented.
C1 Masumoto, Kimio; Kamezawa 3 Chrome 14-13-1001,Sumida Ku, Tokyo, 1300014,
   Japan, Japan.

   Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Ziaelas fujiokai [Vietnam /  / New species].

   record].

TI Taxonomic Notes on the Genus Procleomenes Gressitt & Rondon (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) from the Philippine Islands.
AU Niisato, Tatsuya
   Tichy, Tomas
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 215-221
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philippine species of the genus Procleomenes Gressitt & Rondon are
   discussed. Procleomenes negrosus sp. nov. is described from Negros Is.
   and the male genital organs of P. bifasciatus Vives is described. A key
   to the Philippine species of the genus is provided.

   related to P. jousselini Guerin-Meneville, 1836 and its allied species.

TI A New Species of Isomyia (Diptera: Calliphoridae) from Thailand, with
   the Revised Key to the Known Species.
AU Kurahashi, Hiromu
   Sukontason, Kabkaew L.
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 227-230
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species of the genus Isomyia Walker is described and illustrated
   from the northern Thailand, which is closely allied to Isomyia dotata
   (Walker), but differs from the latter in bearing pteropleural hairs
   yellow and postsutural ac 3.

DT Article
TI Review of Protodexiini (Sarcophagidae, Diptera) from Oriental and
   Australasian/Oceanian Regions with a Description of a New Species.
AU Verves, Yuriy (fly_@voliacable.com) 
   Xue, Wan-Qi
   Wang, Ping
   Khrokalo, Luydmyla
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 231-240
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the tribe Protodexiini with a key to genera and subgenera is
   presented. This tribe belonging to the subfamily Sarcophaginae, consists
   from 7 genera and 226 species and distributes in all zoogeographic
   regions, except Antarctic. Lists of all genera, subgenera and species
   are presented; faunistic and ecological review of species from Oriental
   and Australasian/Oceanian regions are published too. A new Oriental
   species, Blaesoxipha hainanensis Xue, Verves, Wang et Khrokalo, is
   described. Genera and subgenera Helicobiella Blanchard, 1939: 837, syn.
   n., Neotephromyiella Blanchard, 1955, syn. n., Blaesoxiphomima Verves,
   1985, syn. n. are designated as synonymes of genus Mantidophaga
   Townsend, 1919; Sarpedia Roback, 1954, syn. n. - as a synonym of genus
   Tephromyia Brauer et Bergenstamm, 1891. 5 new special synonymes are
   given: Blaesoxipha qiana Wei & Yang, 2007, syn. n. synonymized with
   Blaesoxipha lautaretensis Villeneuve, 1928; Blaesoxipha lungleiana
   Lehrer, 2010, syn. n. synonymized with Blaesoxipha pygmaea (Zetterstedt,
   1844); Blaesoxipha fanjingensis Wei, 2006, syn. n. synonymized with
   Blaesoxipha rufipes (Macquart, 1839); Blaesoxipha cladorosa Wei & Yang,
   2007, syn. n. synonymized with Blaesoxipha unicolor (Villeneuve, 1912);
   Blaesoxipha bangaloria Lehrer, 2010, syn. n. synonymized with
   Blaesoxipha valangae (Aldrich, 1932). Such 56 new combinations are
   proposed: Acanthodotheca aix (Pape, 1994), comb. IL; A. akrolophos
   (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. angul (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. apertella
   (Parker, 1920), comb. n.; A. arizona (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. atrox
   (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. boreas (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. brazil
   (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. castus (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. cerkyma
   (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. diloboderi (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A.
   ejuncida (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. enotah (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A.
   gibberis (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. gongros (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A.
   gracilis (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. laguna (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A.
   lilloet (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. lingua (Pape, 1994), comb. A.
   melanderi (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. occidens (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A.
   oriens (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. phaneophaga (Blanchard, 1966), comb.
   n.; A. saccata (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. santafe (Pape, 1994), comb.
   n.; A. spiniger (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; A. torreya (Pape, 1994), comb.
   n.; A. tricuspis (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; Agriella agutiana (Lehrer,
   2002), comb. n.; A. tunisia (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; Mantidophaga
   casuarius (Pape, 1984), comb. n.; M. chubutina (Blanchard, 1955), comb.
   n.; M. hospes (Aldrich, 1916), comb. n.; M. mixta (Rohdendorf, 1928),
   comb. n.; M. shelkovnikovi (Rohdendorf, 1937), comb. n.; M. spatulata
   (Aldrich, 1916), comb. n.; Servaisia (Acridiophaga) aldrichia (Pape,
   1994), comb. n.; S. (A.) amblycolyphae (Coquillett, 1904), comb. n.; S.
   (A.) americana (Brauer, 1898), comb. n.; S. (A.) convena (Reinhard,
   1947), comb. n.; S. (A.) dolosa (Dodge, 1966), comb. n.; S. (A.) ebi
   (Hall, 1937), comb. n.; S. (A.) fazi (Hall, 1937), comb. n.; S. (A.)
   kyrton (Pape, 1994), comb. n.; S. (A.) kyrtonidion (Pape, 1994), comb.
   n.; S. (A.) rimosa (Hall, 1938), comb. n.; S. (A.) tingomaria (Pape,
   1984), comb. n.; S. (A.) utah (Pape, 1984), comb. n.; Tephromyia ibe
   (Pape, 1984), comb. n.; T. neuquenensis (Blanchard, 1942), comb. n.; T.
   quaesita (Hall, 1937), comb. n.; T. setigera (Aldrich, 1916), comb. n.;
   T. steyskali (Pape, 1984), comb. n.; T. tingomaria (Pape, 1984), comb.
   n.; T. zaitzevi (Rohdendorf & Verves, 1979), comb. n.
C1 Verves, Yuriy; Natl Acad Sci Ukraine, Inst Evolutionary Ecol,
   Academician Lebedev Str 37, Kiev, UA-03143, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM fly_@voliacable.com
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Australasian region; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Blaesoxipha hainanensis [Hainan /  / New species]. 
   Protodexiini [Oriental region /  / Systematics] [Australasia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Sarcophagidae

   combination not given, p. 233].

   Previous combination not given, p. 233].

   from Japan.

PT J
AN ZOOR15306038011
DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Chilocoris Mayr from Japan, with Special
   Reference to the Morphology of its Internal Organs (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Cydnidae).
AU Imura, Jimpei (imu-jim.2-21@qc.commufa.jp) 
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 249-264
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Chilocoris, Ch. platycephalus n. sp., from
   Japan, is described. The new species belongs to the nitidus-group of
   this genus, and appears more closely related to Himalayan
   representatives of this species group, such as Ch. brunneus Lis and Ch.
   nepalensis Lis, than to the other Japanese representative, Ch. monticola
   Imura. Diagnostic characters of Ch. platycephalus n. sp. are discussed
   and compared with those of Himalayan relatives. The alimentary organs,
   and the male and female internal reproductive organs, of this new
   species are also described and illustrated. Comparisons between the
   Chilocoris representatives and other bugs highlight the unique organ
   characteristics of this genus. The alimentary canal of Chilocoris, for
   example, notably lacks midgut gastric caeca, unlike the related genus,
   Cydnus, whose midgut has a highly developed caecal segment. The male
   internal genitalia of this genus are also unusual among the Cydnidae, as
   well as within the superfamily Pentatomoidea. The testis comprises
   freely separate, bulbous follicles, and the efferent system lacks
   ectadenia and possesses only a single pair of simple, lobe-like
   mesadenia. Among other cydnines, the testicular follicles are sheathed
   in each testis, and both the mesadenia and ectadenia are well developed
   and elaborated. The male accessory glands may also influence the
   structure of female genitalia, especially the spermatheca, which
   receives the products of those glands during copulation. The
   evolutionary significance of these characteristics in Chilocoris is
   discussed, and the biological knowledge of this genus is surveyed in
   this context.
C1 Imura, Jimpei; Viva Esperanza 307,Mitada Kita Dori 18-1, Okazaki, Aichi,
   4440011, Japan, Japan.
EM imu-jim.2-21@qc.commufa.jp
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Evolution; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chilocoris [General morphology / Internal anatomy / ] [Evolution /  / ].
   
   Chilocoris platycephalus [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Pentatomomorpha,
   Pentatomoidea, Cydnidae
OR Chilocoris (Cydnidae). 
   Chilocoris platycephalus (Cydnidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 250]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15306038011
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15306038012
DT Article
TI A New Species of Halictophagus (Strepsiptera: Halictophagidae)
   Parasitizing in the Genus Cacopsylla (Hemiptera, Psyllidae) from Japan.
AU Nakase, Yuta
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 265-267
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Halictophagus inouei sp. nov. is described from specimens parasitic to
   Cacopsylla swidae Inoue, 2004 and Cacopsylla yukawai Inoue, 2004
   collected from Japan. It is the first record of strepsipteran parasite
   of psyllid from Japan. The new species is clearly distinguished
   morphologically and its host utilization by other described
   Halictophagus.
C1 Nakase, Yuta; Natl Museum Nat & Sci, Dept Zool, Amakubo 4-1-1, Tsukuba,
   Ibaraki, 3050005, Japan, Japan.

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Taxonomic Report on Catops hilleri Species Group (Coleoptera: Leiodidae:
   Cholevinae), (II).
AU Hoshina, Hideto
   Hayashi, Yasuhiko
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 287-290
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Catops Paykull, 1798 (Coleoptera: Leiodidae:
   Cholevinae), Catops saitoae Hoshina & Hayashi, sp. nov., is described
   from Honshu, Japan. C. saitoae sp. nov. is very similar to Catops
   luridipennis asiaticus Jeannel, 1936 and C. hilleri Kraatz, 1877 in
   appearance, but can be distinguished from them by morphological features
   of male median lobe of aedeagus. The present new species is a member of
   C. hilleri species group.
C1 Hoshina, Hideto; Fukui Univ, Fac Educ, Fukui, 9108507, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Leiodidae

AN ZOOR15306038017
DT Article
TI Studies on the Flightless Lamiinae (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae) from
   China, I. Revision of the Genus Echthistatodes Gressitt, 1938 and its
   Allied Genera with Description of One New Genus, Two New Species and One
   New Subspecies.
AU Bi, Wen-Xuan
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 22
IS 2
PS 291-301
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Echthistatodes Gressitt, 1938 is revised and redefined, and
   the male of its type species, E. brunneus Gressitt, 1938 is described
   for the first time. Echthistatodes gongshanus sp. nov. is described from
   Yunnan as the third species of the genus. A morphologically similar
   genus Petromorphus gen. nov. is established for Petromorphus yunnanus
   sp. nov. and Petromorphus yunnanus australis ssp. nov. Another three
   allied genera Centruroides Breuning, 1940, Centruropsis Breuning, 1950
   and Falsotrachystola Breuning, 1950 are reviewed base on the type
   specimen or fresh materials for a comparison with the new genus.
   Endophallic structure of Echthistatodes Gressitt, 1938, Falsotrachystola
   Breuning, 1950 and Petromorphus gen. nov. in inflated and everted
   condition are investigated and discussed. Illustrations of habitus and
   major diagnostic features for all new taxa are provided.
C1 Bi, Wen-Xuan; Room 401,2,Lane 155,Lianhua South Rd, Shanghai, 201100,
   China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   species]. 
   Petromorphus yunnanaus australis [Yunnan /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Echthistatodes - Gressitt 1938 (Cerambycidae): [Revision, P. 292;
   Redescription, P. 292]. 
   Echthistatodes brunneus - Gressitt 1938 (Cerambycidae): [First time
   described, Male, p. 292]. 
   Echthistatodes gongshanus (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 296]. 
   Echthistatodes subobscurus - Holzschuh 1993 (Cerambycidae):
   [Redescription, P. 295]. 
   Falsotrachystola asidiformis - (Pie 1915) (Cerambycidae):
   [Redescription, P. 298]. 
   Petromorphus (Cerambycidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Lamiini, Type species
   Petromorphus yunnanus, p. 299]. 
   Petromorphus yunnanaus australis (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Yunnan, P.
   300].

DT Article
TI New Species of Euryglossula Michener (Apoidea: Colletidae).
AU Batley, Michael (michael.batley@gmail.com) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 68
IS 6
PS 245-261
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eleven new species of Euryglossula Michener are described: E. aeneoceps,
   E. elizabethae, E. eremophilae, E. incisa, E. kubinensis, E. laticeps,
   E. pallida, E. pinnulata, E. purpurea, E. scalaris and E. storeyi. The
   male of E. variepicta Exley is described for the first time. As now
   understood, the genus Euryglossula contains 18 species. New floral
   records and illustrated identification keys for both sexes of all
   species of the genus are provided. Variations in some diagnostic
   features of Euryglossula and the taxonomic placement of some species are
   discussed.

   William St, Sydney, NSW, 2010, Australia, Australia.

DT Article
TI An Unusual New Leioproctus Species (Hymenoptera: Colletidae).
AU Batley, Michael (michael.batley@gmail.com) 
   Popic, Tony J.
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 68
IS 6
PS 263-268
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Leioproctus glendae Batley, n. sp., is described on the basis of two
   males and one female from western Queensland. The female has an
   unusually narrow fore basitarsus and mandibular structure not seen in
   other members of the genus, while the male terminalia do not closely
   resemble those of any other species group. The new species provides
   further demonstration of the variety of forms contained in the genus
   Leioproctus, and is described in order to assist future revision of this
   group.
C1 Batley, Michael; Australian Museum, Australian Museum Res Inst, 1
   William St, Sydney, NSW, 2010, Australia, Australia.
EM michael.batley@gmail.com
OI Batley, Michael/0000-0001-9191-4286

   Australasia; Australia

   Colletidae

   264].

TI Revision of the Genus Anisolepisma (Zygentoma: Lepismatidae:
   Acrotelsatinae).
AU Smith, Graeme B. (le_gbsmith@optusnet.com.au) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 68
IS 6
PS 269-312
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The morphology of the enigmatic silverfish genus Anisolepisma Paclt is
   clarified with a redescription of the type species and the description
   of three new species. The genus is placed within the subfamily
   Acrotelsatinae and its relevance to the phylogeny and zoogeography of
   the Lepismatidae discussed. Paracrotelsa Paclt is also placed within the
   Acrotelsatinae.

PT J

PM 27902710
DT Article
TI Aspergillus sydowii and Other Potential Fungal Pathogens in Gorgonian
   Octocorals of the Ecuadorian Pacific.
AU Soler-Hurtado, M. Mar
   Sandoval-Sierra, Jose Vladimir
   Machordom, Annie
   Dieguez-Uribeondo, Javier (dieguez@rjb.csic.es) 
SO PLoS ONE
VL 11
IS 11
PS e0165992
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB Emerging fungal diseases are threatening ecosystems and have increased
   in recent decades. In corals, the prevalence and consequences of these
   infections have also increased in frequency and severity. Coral reefs
   are affected by an emerging fungal disease named aspergillosis, caused
   by Aspergillus sydowii. This disease and its pathogen have been reported
   along the Caribbean and Pacific coasts of Colombia. Despite this, an
   important number of coral reefs worldwide have not been investigated for
   the presence of this pathogen. In this work, we carried out the
   surveillance of the main coral reef of the Ecuadorian Pacific with a
   focus on the two most abundant and cosmopolitan species of this
   ecosystem, Leptogorgia sp. and Leptogorgia obscura. We collected 59
   isolates and obtained the corresponding sequences of the Internal
   Transcribed Spacers (ITS) of the ribosomal DNA. These were
   phylogenetically analyzed using MrBayes, which indicated the presence of
   two isolates of the coral reef pathogen A. sydowii, as well as 16
   additional species that are potentially pathogenic to corals. Although
   the analyzed gorgonian specimens appeared healthy, the presence of these
   pathogens, especially of A. sydowii, alert us to the potential risk to
   the health and future survival of the Pacific Ecuadorian coral ecosystem
   under the current scenario of increasing threats and stressors to coral
   reefs, such as habitat alterations by humans and global climate change.
C1 Dieguez-Uribeondo, Javier; Real Jardin Bot CSIC, Dept Micol, Madrid,
   Spain, Spain.
EM dieguez@rjb.csic.es
RI Machordom, Annie/K-1737-2014; Sandoval Sierra, Jose Vladimir/B-7111-2015
OI Machordom, Annie/0000-0003-0341-0809; Sandoval Sierra, Jose
   Vladimir/0000-0003-2007-6582
SC Physiology; Zoology; Infectious Diseases; Mycology
SN 1932-6203
BD Whole animal physiology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and
   disorders; Microbial diseases; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Leptogorgia; Leptogorgia obscura [Physiological condition /  / molecular
   & phylogenetic analysis] [Fungal diseases /  / ] [South Pacific /
   Ecuador, Manabi, Machalilla National Park / ]. 
   Octocorallia [Fungal diseases / Aspergillus sydowii / New record] [South
   Pacific / Ecuador / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Octocorallia
OR Octocorallia (Anthozoa): [New record]. 
   Leptogorgia (Octocorallia). 
   Leptogorgia obscura (Octocorallia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15303017284

DT Article
TI A new cave species of Coecobrya Yosii (Collembola, Entomobryidae,
   Entomobryinae) from South Africa, with an identification key to the
   genus.
AU Cipola, Nikolas Gioia
   Bellini, Bruno Cavalcante (entobellini@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4200
IS 3
PS 351-366
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Coecobrya anaguilae sp. nov., a new species of springtail from Cango
   Caves, South Africa is described and illustrated. The new species is
   similar to other species of tenebricosa-group such as C. communis (Chen
   & Christiansen), C. edenticulata (Handschin), and C. tropicalis Qu, Chen
   & Greenslade in some elements of dorsal chaetotaxy, absence of eyes,
   unguis with one unpaired median tooth, and manubrium without smooth
   chaetae, but differs from them in dorsal head, mesothoracic and
   collophore chaetotaxy. This is the first species of Coecobrya described
   from Africa as well as the first indisputable record of the genus for
   the whole continent. In this study an updated key to the species of the
   genus is provided, adding 14 species to the most recently published
   identification key. We also discuss some aspects of distribution and
   evolution of Coecobrya.
C1 Bellini, Bruno Cavalcante; Univ Fed Rio Grande Norte, Programa Posgrad
   Sistemat & Evolucao, Rodovia BR 101,Campus Univ, Natal, RN, BR-59072970
   BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM entobellini@gmail.com
RI Cipola, Nikolas G./O-2125-2016; Bellini, Bruno/N-5093-2016
OI Cipola, Nikolas G./0000-0002-7594-9574; Bellini,
   Bruno/0000-0001-7881-9436
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Coecobrya [Africa /  / New record]. 
   Coecobrya anaguilae [South Africa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Collembola

   subordinate taxa, P. 360; Emended diagnosis, P. 353; Key to species,
   Updated key, p. 363; New record]. 
   Coecobrya anaguilae (Collembola): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 353].

DT Article
TI Two remarkable new species of Hypothenemus Westwood (Curculionidae:
   Scolytinae) from Southeastern USA.
AU Johnson, Andrew J. (andrewjavanjohnson@gmail.com) 
   Atkinson, Thomas H.
   Hulcr, Jiri
SO Zootaxa
VL 4200
IS 3
PS 417-425
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new Hypothenemus species found in southern and southeastern USA are
   described: Hypothenemus piaparolinae sp. n. and Hypothenemus
   subterrestris sp. n. The distribution and habits suggest these species
   are native and widely distributed, but elusive, and not recently arrived
   exotics. Both appear to have unusual biology: H. subterrestris appears
   to live in material on or in the ground, and H. piaparolinae has only
   been collected from the xylem of extensively rotten, fungusfilled twigs.

DT Article
TI Papuaneon, a new genus of jumping spiders from Papua New Guinea
   (Araneae: Salticidae: Neonini).
AU Maddison, Wayne P. (wayne.maddison@ubc.ca) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4200
IS 3
PS 437-443
PD Nov 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB The genus Neon Simon stands alone as a phylogenetically isolated astioid
   jumping spider, the only member of the Neonini. The new genus Papuaneon
   is established for the jumping spider Papuaneon tualapa sp. nov. from
   Papua New Guinea. Resembling a large, hirsute Neon, it is here shown to
   be the sister group to Neon, based on data from the nuclear 28S and
   Actin 5C, and the mitochondrial 16SND1 region. Photographs of living
   specimens are provided.
C1 Maddison, Wayne P.; Univ British Columbia, Dept Bot & Zool, 6270 Univ
   Blvd, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada, Canada.
EM wayne.maddison@ubc.ca
SC Zoology

   Australasia

   tualapa, p. 438].
